Story #2

  • March 01, 2021
  • Zizi

You might have noticed that I mentioned past life memories before which might seem weird. Well, my weirdness started early. When I was 5 my father died of cardiac arrest. His body was lying in a coffin in the main room. Me, my elder brother and mother were sleeping together in the bedroom. I woke up in the middle of the night and I saw a boy standing by my side of a bed. He had black curly hair and striped white t-shirt. I knew this is my father. I looked in the main room, his body was still in the coffin. He extended his hand to me and wanted me to give him my hand. I got scared. I did not know what to do. So I turned to my mother saying that father came. She said to sleep. When I turned back he was gone. I have not seen him since.

After my father’s death my mother sold the house and moved us into an apartment in a five-story apartment building. In this move I lost all my toys, because my mother decided I don’t need them anymore, and a cat. Our dog got hit by a car not long before my father’s death. Our cat used to do his business outside, so he started doing it in the apartment building’s corridor. One day he disappeared. I was looking for him for quite a while, checking every cat looking like him. I have never seen him again. Years after I learned that our neighbors took our cat, drove to the forest and left him there.

In this apartment building I met my first friend Tony. He was living right across the corridor. His mother was a tall, nice and kind lady. She was always attentive to me. They had a tiny little dog named Milo, exactly the same as in a film “The Mask”, which was popular at those times, and a turtle, which I saw for the first time in my life. Their home felt so warm and welcome.

We went to the same special school with Tony. The drawing school decided to make a gymnasium class in our city, which meant that those kids, who were lucky to get in it, will learn two foreign languages, get art, drawing and dance classes extra from a normal school programme. So we both got that luck.

One winter day after school we went to jump down the hill in the snow. At those times winter brought an insane amount of snow and -30 to -40 degrees below 0. Every time we jumped we got stuck really deep in the snow and could hardly pull each other out. But we kept going to the moment when we could not get out. It was getting dark and freezing. We were yelling for help, but none of passers-by paid any attention. Finally, one girl walking on top of a hill saw us, paid attention and helped. We were scared, so she decided to entertain us and showed a machine with some cables which showed the multiplication of different numbers. I still remember her face and her very rare name Agnetta because she was so kind and ready to help.

I was not very good with numbers at the beginning, so I could not understand the multiplication thing and could not memorize it. My mother asked her boyfriend to help. After some time trying to pull right answers from me, he lost his patience and beat me with a leather belt. My conclusion after this was obvious: “Never ask for help”. This thing is a tough one. It makes a child feel totally alone and lonely. This pushes to realization that he/she has to face life on his/her own, which leads to serious tension, emotional pain and inability to trust and rely on people. It might seem like a good turn for one being responsible for one’s own actions, but there is one more element in this which is a feeling of weakness and hopefulness because you are still a child and depend on caregivers anyways. So you have to face your life on your own, but you still have to behave in a way your parents want you. So it is like you are between a rock and a hard place because you can not choose anything freely. You always have to look around if your action goes according to their rules and opinions, no matter what you face in your life.

There were some unbreakable rules in my mother’s house:

1. Never come later from the time she said you must be at home otherwise you’ll be beaten and grounded for a period of time.

I remember one time I went to our upstairs neighbour my mothers husband’s sister. We had a great time with her daughter, sitting in her room, listening to the music and talking. I noticed that I’m getting late, but my mother did not call or come. I thought: “Great! I can have some extra nice time here”. But. The door bell rang and my mother was standing at their door asking for me to come. As soon as the door was closed I got slapped and started to fall down the stairs following with slaps and words of abuse and anger. At one moment I folded on a railing, thinking may be I can get up before the next slap and run down the stairs and out of the building but the slap got me earlier than I could do any move. I was roughly pushed into the apartment and then finally left along.

2. Smile and behave normal, does not matter how you feel and what happened.

In our special class we celebrated all together birthdays and some holidays. This tradition made us a real group and we were hanging out all together all the time. One time there was a birthday celebration and a class teacher was making riddles and gave praises for right answers. Once I said a right answer for a riddle but the teacher did not pay attention. I repeated it and she did not noticed again. Then the girl next to me repeated my answer and was immediately herd and got a praise. My mother saw it and did nothing. I left the class, ran into the corridor, and sat on the stairs crying. It felt so not fear and I felt weak and lonely. No one stood up for me. My mother came to me, saw me crying and saying: “this is unfair”. She slapped me in the head saying: “You now go back, smile and play with others!” And I did so with a feeling of being betrayed and having no one on my side.

3. You do what I say, period.

I was a child who was super curious to know and understand things. So I was asking questions all the time. But there was no one ready to answer. I think this is partially why teaches never liked me. It was unnecessary extra work to answer my questions. I was looking for answers everywhere because my mother never really spent any time explaining things. Everything must be done the way she wants otherwise punishment was coming. I remember one day my brother’s friend came to our apartment. And I liked him so much that I wanted him to stay forever. So I hid his shoes in a wardrobe. When his time to leave came he could not find the shoes. My mother figured out that I must be involved in this. I was kind of always guilty in any mess in the house. So she asked me and I did not answer, I decided to hold on. So as we know her as a short-tempered person I got beaten with the leather belt pretty fast and showed the shoes in a wardrobe. As we see: do what is asked or get beaten. The chose was obvious.

And the last thing

Verbal and physical abuse was normal for my mother and her partner. Humiliation and insult were a part of my daily life. Mother’s husband played a fine guy till the moment he got his own child. My elder brother and I immediately became a burden. I had lots of nights talking to my staffed cat, who was definitely my best friend and the only one whom I could talk with. I felt like I was from an orphanage. At that time I was planing on running away from the house. The first variant was to get on the train to another city, but the chances to get caught were pretty high, and what to do next was not clear. The second variant was to get to our garden on a distance from the city and start living there. When people come to work there I was planing to hide in the forest, but come back to our land at night to eat what was growing on the land and sleep in a green house. That plan was pretty reasonable, and I could definitely hold on for the summer. But I was so scared to be bitten by my mother to death when she will find me. So I never made a try. That fear led to a strong feeling of hopelessness and that there is no way out of this. Verbal abuse led to negative self-esteem and zero self-confidence. At the same time relying on myself taught me to be really brave. There were lots of situations when I faced scary things with a cold head and plain face. I’ll tell you one. Once I rescued my two girl classmates from being beaten in a dark park by another strong girl. I was a great diplomat and made a superb speech on their behalf. Ones there was a party and all schools were invited. According to the girl’s street rules you were supposed to dance and date with the boys from your school only. But I did not agree to this rule and when a guy from another school invited me for a dance I agreed and had a nice slow dance. After I went to a washroom. As soon as I entered the room six girls from that other school came into the room as well as those two rescued girls. As soon as they saw me surrounded by the girls from another school they immediately left. So I was standing with those girls, and we started a conversation. At the end of it we came to a conclusion that actually it’s pretty cool to have a choice among a big amount of boys from any school in the city. There were three of them at that time. After that I was surrounded by girls in different times and cities, and I was always brave enough to stay and talk or fight if this would be needed. But fortunately talking was always good enough.
